div.p: 1. IV.30— Wednesday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. Mr Read was here again and took the day to clean the kitchen Clock. I planted between the young Horse Chesnut trees under the Eastern fence, the last division towards the Garden Corner 6 whole Pears, with Horse Plum-Stones between them and steeped huckleberries, and Willow and Water Oak Acorns— Then more superficially over them, Ash pods, Apple-seeds and one plum stone— Then from stoney-barren, the centre of the Nursery; one division up towards the fence 2. Plum stones and a row of Apple seeds. Gathered part of the Brazilian Beans, and wind-fallen overhanging Apples— The two shoots from the Willow, that I had headed down grew, from the 20th. of June to the 16th. of August about half an Inch a day. They were then 28 inches long, and ceased growing— The English Oaks still grow, but none others. The Elms also seem to have ceased growing— I wrote this afternoon to Lieutt. T. B. Adams informing him that I had purchased for him ten shares of the Boylston Market Stock, giving him the option to take them or not. Charles’s wife took tea at my brothers and Charles and I walked there in the Evening.
2. IV.30. Thursday.

Planted a row at the bottom of the Nursery, with a stake marked Peach, Pear, Plum, Apple, Ash, Bass, with steeped huckleberries; all in two layers, digging trenches, in the Stoney barren part of the enclosure— General Sumner called with his wife’s Son, and brought me a small box of the Downton Strawberry Roots. After dinner I had a Cucumber Vine plucked up, and the Straw-berry Roots planted in its place, in four Rows— General Sumner was going to Weymouth where he owns a Waterfall, which he wishes to turn to account— General Morton of New-York, paid us an after-noon visit with Coll. Quincy— He goes upon his return to New-York tomorrow— Mr Vose of Milton and of Louisiana came and introduced Mrs Montgomery of New-Orleans. In the Evening a young man named Thacher, of Portland, Maine came and introduced himself— He had written to me making enquiry for papers relating to the Life of Commodore Samuel Tucker which he proposed to write. I answered him that I had received a previous application from another person with the approbation of Commodore Tucker himself— Notwithstanding which he came this Evening with the apparent intention of renewing his application, to which I gave however no encouragement— My wife and two daughters rode in the Carriage this afternoon, and I rode with John round the Gulliver’s Brook Square— Examined Oaks, black, white and Gray—found a few acorns of the last—not ripe— Finished reading the first Book Cicero de Natura Deorum, and the Translation of D’Olivet— This work is addressed like that de Finibus, and the Tusculans to Marcus Brutus—and like all the philosophical Treatises begins with an apology for writing upon the subject at all. Then follows a dialogue supposed to have taken place at the villa of Caius Cotta; to which he invites Cicero during the Fariae Latini— There he meets Velleius an Epicurean, and Cornelius Balbus a Stoic; both Senators— In this first book Velleius adopts the opinions of Epicurus concerning the Nature of the Gods, and gives historically an account of the Speculations of all the Greek philosophers upon this question— From Thales of Miletus; the first of the Greeks who reasoned high on this topic, down to Carneades, the last of the originating Greek Philosophers. Velleius states successively all the Greek theories concerning the Gods; shews the absurdity of them all, and then extols Epicurus as the great discoverer of truth, and liberator from the errors of superstition. He is answered by Cotta the Academician, who without very forcibly sustaining the other philosophers, abundantly shews the absurdity of the Epicurean Creed. The moon rose this evening totally eclipsed— About 2 hours passing off.
3. III.30 Friday.

A man named Dexter, brother of Richard Dexter who lived many years with my father, as this man himself afterwards did, came to enquire if I would sell about 50 acres of my land at Weston for 9 dollars an acre— I told him I had only a Life interest in the Estate; but the owners of the remainder would perhaps join in the conveyance if a suitable price should be offered for the land— That I should however not consider an offer of one thousand dollars for the 50 Acres as acceptable— This morning I worked two full hours in my Nursery, the sole bodily exercise of the day, chiefly employed in digging trenches for planting my seeds— At the centre of my enclosure there seems to be a rock under the surface— In two or
three places it appears even above the surface; and in digging the Spade turns up nothing but gravel, and loose Stones of various sizes— On this ground all the trees that came up from seeds or stones which I planted, have perished the second or third winter after planting; but some of the thriftiest trees are in the immediate neighbourhood. The finest of our forest trees grow on rocky and stony ground, and where their roots have room to creep between the Stones, they are supported and perhaps protected from vermine by them. I am digging a trench from this Centre over the Stony-barren up to the Nursery gate— It is divided by young horse chesnuts at intervals, and I renew the experiment of raising trees from the seed on this ground— I dig the trench nearly a foot deep— Fill it about half up with rich mould from the garden— Then plant a row of peach and plum stones— Of Apple and Pear seeds; with Basswood seeds, year steeped huckleberries, Willow and Water Oak acorns and Ash pods—cover them all with another Spade full of rich Garden mould and cover the whole with the gravelly earth first dug from the trench— I began this work this morning; and it will take me ten days to get up to the fence— Of the Stones that I dig up some split in layers like Slates— Made a temporary deposit of the small Stone marked Alteri Seculo, by the young growing red Oak in the Nursery; the only Oak of my planting which survives in that enclosure: and which if it lives, I intend shall stand where it now is— This is the first anniversary of my Son Charles’s Marriage— He went to Boston, and returned— My brother, his wife, his daughter Abigail and Louisa C. Smith dined with us. My brother thinks the devastation of my Indian corn patch at the bottom of the Nursery, is the work of the little striped Squirrel. I began reading the second Book de Natura Deorum.
4. III.15. Saturday.

The night was cool— The morning Summer heat and a scorching Sun— The afternoon again chilly; with an Eastern wind. An hour in the Nursery, making progress upward from Stony-barren to the Nursery gate. Planted in two short divisions, in a layer of garden mould, Peach and Plum Stones, Apple, Pear, and Bass wood seeds; Water and Willow, Oak Acorns— I dug up a Spanish Chesnut, planted about six weeks since, which I found hard, swollen and heavy— Replanted it at the bottom of the Nursery; under the growing Elms— Having risen so early, the day was longer than usual, and I began the examination and arrangement of my fathers papers; to which I devoted one hour before and two hours after dinner. The papers are in such total disorder that the arrangement of them will occupy several Months— My Sons with Charles’s wife spent the Evening at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— I walked to my brother’s.
5. V. Sunday.

Heard Dr Richmond; of Dorchester in the morning from Jude 3. “Beloved, when I gave all diligence to write unto you, of the common salvation, it was needful for me to write unto you, and exhort you, that ye should earnestly contend for the faith which was once delivered unto the Saints,” and in the afternoon from Isaiah 1.17. [“]Learn to do well[”]—both discourses were ingenious, well written and closely reason—defensive of Unitarianism and argumentative against the Calvinistic doctrines of election and the five points— In replying to the objection that the Unitarians profess none of the important doctrines of Christianity he enumerated, the belief of one omnipotent God the creator and Governor of the Universe—the immortality of the Soul, and a future state of retribution— The divine mission of Jesus Christ, the acknowledgment of his authority, and of his mediatorial character as the redeemer of the world, and the admitted obligation of conforming to the moral precepts promulgated by him
all of which he considered as highly important.— From his short text of the afternoon “Learn to do well,” he deduced an inference against the doctrine of total depravity of man—for to do well he observed comprized the whole sum of human duties; and the injunction of the prophet to learn to do well, necessarily implied the capacity of man to acquire the practice of doing well. It necessarily implied that man might learn to do well if he would, and that virtue or transgression are voluntary— It were an absurd command, to learn that which the scholar has not the capacity to learn, and worse than idle waste of words in the prophet to give the instruction, knowing that he who received it had no power to carry it into effect. Dr Richmond’s delivery is cold and monotonous. He dined with us— And Louisa C. Smith— Coll. Quincy lent me a Newspaper, containing accounts from France through Liverpool— A new Revolution— Charles the 15th. expelled from Paris—the Duke of Orleans Lieutenant General of the kingdom La Fayette again Commander of the National Guards— There was a rumour of these Events yesterday, which I hastily discredited. The explosion took place at Paris on the 29th. of July— Mr Degrand walked out from Boston, and passes the Night here— My brother and Mr Edward Miller called upon us this Evening.
6. IV. Monday.

Mr Degrand went into Boston this morning with Charles, who returned here to dine— Alpheus Spear one of my Tenants of the Mount Wollaston farm came, and afterwards sent me a second load of wood— He was going this day to Brighton, to purchase Cattle, to drive into Rhode-Island for Sale— He told me he had sold between one and two hundred head in the last fortnight— He borrows from the Bank to make his capital— I continued my planting in the Nursery, pursuing my experiments on the Stony-barren— There was room for remarking upon the formation of the Stones and rocks under the Surface— I overfatigued myself— Youth may acquire hardihood by hard labour; but it suits not the infirmity of old Age— I resumed the assortment of my father’s papers, and found that this will prove another laborious task— I shall divide his correspondence Alphabetically, and Chronologically, but cannot get through with it before the winter— My attention was arrested by a number of Letters received by my father in the years 1780 and 1781 from a correspondent in England, who dates every Letter from a different place, subscribes several fictitious names, Church, Ross and Russell, and addresses the Letters to a fictitious Spanish name at Amsterdam— I found Letters from Samuel Adams, Dr Cooper, T. Dalton, William and Arthur Lee, and General James Warren, and his wife— Scarcely one of these Letters repays the trouble of reading it— Scarcely one deserved to be kept— They are neither lively, nor ingenious, nor indicative of mind in the writer— There is some pompous inanity in the Letters of Mrs Warren— Much mortified pride— Jealousy and Envy of Hancock—rankling discontent at her own situation, and with constant professions of ardent friendship a querulous tone of remark, and perpetual ebullitions of Spleen, at the contrast between the Cottage and the Court, Milton Hill, and the Palaces of Versailles and St. James’s. Mrs Warren was a woman of uncommon Powers; with grasp of intellect adequate to the composition and publication of two sleepy Tragedies, and a History equally dull of the American Revolution in three Volumes— Ambitious as Catherine of Anhalt Zerbst, sister of James Otis, and linked to a husband much inferior to herself though not altogether obscure in the American Revolution, she had five Sons, in childhood the finest and most promising boys that I ever knew, but every one of whom had a disastrous Life. The youngest of them is I believe yet living; I know not where— I rode this afternoon with John to Randolph, returning by the Turnpike and Cold Water Corner.
7. IV:15. Tuesday— Squantum.

Charles and his wife were to have left us this morning; but a north-easterly rain came on, which suspended their visit to Medford. Charles went to Boston, and came back to dine. My Nursery labours were interrupted, and the rain forced me to take refuge in the house. I planted on one division of the Stony-barren, alternate peach and Plum stones; with Apple and Bass wood seeds—first partly filling the trench with mould from the Garden— Annual meeting of the proprietors of Neponset Bridge— I dined with them at Squantum— The road for a quarter of a mile was overflowed by the tide— Thomas Greenleaf G. W. Beale, and Edward Miller, were the only proprietors there—my brother and Mr Miller’s brother in Law Spooner were also there. The place was dreary with a stubborn North easter, and we adjourned soon after five. I finished reading the second Book de Natura Deorum— The whole book is occupied by Lucilius Balbus, with an exposition of the Stoic doctrines concerning the Gods— His disquisition is in four parts— 1. to prove their existence. 2. what they are. 3. That the world is governed by them. 4. That they take interest in human affairs— The proof of the existence of the Gods is in the first sixteen Sections—and is by no means logical— The only rational argument for the existence of an intelligent creative power, is the creation itself— We everywhere see means adapted to ends.— Intelligence invisible in act—visible in effect, is stamped upon all creation— We find a watch—we infer the watchmaker, because we know the watch could not make itself, and must have had a beginning—but here our evidence stops— By whom or how or when the watch was made, we have nothing to shew— The agent is impenetrably concealed. There may be one; there may be myriads— The Stoics inferred that there were Gods; but as in all the works of creation there is unity of action, it would have been more philosophical to infer unity of the agent— But the Stoics with this natural evidence mingled up the absurdest traditions, and Balbus immediately passes to the fables about Castor and Pollux, augury, the flight of birds and the feeding of Chickens— When he takes up his second point, he makes Gods of the Sun, moon and planets—the courses of which he describes— Next he deifies certain moral properties—such as Faith—the Mind—Virtue—Help, Safety, Concord, Victory—Love, Pleasure and all the Passions— Then distinguished men after death: atmospherical phenomena, Earth, Air and Water— These airy nothings extend to the 29th. Section— The rest of the Book argues the Government of the Gods, from the description of the Constellations, and the natural history of Beasts and Birds— That in all this there is a constant adaptation of cause to effect, Balbus considers as proof that it is all under the Government of the Gods—the whole substance of the argument is embraced in a quotation, Section 37. from Aristotle— There are five Sections from 40 to 44. of extracts from Cicero’s translation of the Astronomical Poem of Aratus—and from Section 56 to the end, the Providence of the Gods is manifested in human concerns, by the corporial and mental organization of man— All Paley’s Natural Theology is here included.
8. III.45. Wednesday.

Second day of rain with little intermission: Charles and his wife are still detained here, and we were all confined at home— There was an interval of cessation to the rain of which I availed myself to visit my Nursery— Planted two decaying whole woodhouse Apples, at the side of the two others in Woodhouse box N. 2. and the core containing the seeds of the Bartlett Pear,
near the centre of Book box N. 3. There are stakes, with them to mark what they are. I would ascertain 1. whether and how the seeds contained in whole Apples will come up— Whether the fruit of Trees from particular Apples and Pears, partake the character of the fruit from which they are planted. The second of these Experiments, presupposes the success of the first, and will require more time, than I have the reasonable expectation to live— But if I have even the next Summer before me, I hope to ascertain some useful facts respecting plantations, and if I can get into the train I may leave the pursuit to those who come after me— I planted also a few peach and Plum-Stones, under the western Wall, in the gravelly stony ground with intermixed Apple and Bass wood seeds— This is to add an experiment upon the Soil, to the others— That of the Stony-barren line is nearly desperate— Plucked a ripe Musk-Melon at the bottom of the Nursery— My industry in the house was somewhat abated— continued reading the third Book de Natura Deorum— After dinner I answered a complementary Letter from Stephen C. Blyth, and A. D. Robinson, at Montreal, Lower Canada.
9. III. Thursday.
Turner Peter

Third day in succession, of rain; which continued all the morning, and held up about Noon. Charles and his wife left us after dinner to visit Mr. Brooks at Medford. There they propose to stay about a fortnight, and then to return to their own house at Boston for the winter. I made a short visit to my Nursery: the ground was too wet for working. My brother was here at noon, and his Sons John Quincy and Joseph Harrod in the Evening. John is to return to his school at Exeter to-morrow. Peter Turner was also here this Evening— I rode towards Evening with my wife to Gullliver’s Brook, and across to the Neponset Bridge Road. My Son John’s wife was unwell and dined in her chamber, but came down to tea— She was soon after taken seriously ill, and Dr Holbrook was sent for before Midnight— I finished reading the third and last Book of Cicero de Natura Deorum; with D’Olivet’s Translation— A great part of it is lost, and a mere fragment remains— In this Book Cotta the Academician, contests the opinions set forth in the preceding Book by Balbus the Stoic, concerning the Nature of the Gods—their superintending Providence, and their Government of the World, and interference in human Affairs— Cotta was a member of the College of Augurs; and Balbus at the close of his discourse reminds him of his official obligation to defend the honour, and maintain the Power of the Gods— Cotta begins by acknowledging all this, and by declaring that in the discharge of his official duties, he always had and always should inflexibly adhere to the established Religion of his Country— That he shall therefore neither deny the existence of the Gods, nor their Providence, nor the share which they take in human affairs— But that now, in a philosophical disquisition, he considers only the positions assumed and the arguments urged by Balbus, to none of which he can yield his assent— He then attacks the whole theology of the Stoics— Without denying the existence of the Gods, he shews that the Mythology of Balbus is utterly absurd. That human Passions and human Virtues and Vices, cannot belong to divine Natures— That of all the principle deities there were several bearing the same name— That to deify, human properties and passions was absurd, and that the Gods evidently take no concern in the affairs of Mankind— The whole objection to the existence of evil is pressed with great energy, but almost all this part of the dialogue has perished— There is reason to believe that the Christians who preserved the works of Cicero, were willing that his argument against divine Providence should not be preserved in all its energy. He concludes the book by observing that after the dialogue was finished, Velleius the Epicurean thought that Cotta had the best of the argument; but that he himself inclined to award the palm of victory to Balbus— In this decision there is apparently more of discretion than of sincerity.
10. V. Friday.

At ten minutes past 12 O’Clock this Morning, my Son John’s wife, it being her own birthday, was happily delivered of her second daughter. Dr Holbrook arrived about half an hour after the child was born— Between one and two Mrs Kirke came to my chamber, for a pillow and told me the child was born— Half an hour later my wife came to bed— Relief from long and deep anxiety. [symbols] I slept no more this Night, but rose only at five. Had a visit from Mr William H. Keating of South-Carolina, who brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Poinsett— Mr Keating was with him some time in Mexico. Mr Willis the Poet accompanied him here. Henry Hardwick came to speak of a small piece of Salt-marshland which he wishes to purchase. Louisa Smith and Abby Adams called in the afternoon— Mr Humphreys the Surveyor came to enquire of his plan of the Penn’s Valley farm which he had left unfinished, and which I had thought of resurveying— I shall see him again on the subject. Mr Savil brought me a Blacksmith’s bill for work last year—and a note of the Quincy Canal Corporation, which I took— I rode towards evening with my wife and John’s eldest child to Braintree. In the Nursery I planted a row of Woodhouse Appleseeds, at the entrance, Westward, marked upon a small thick piece of pine wood, which I deposited upon flat Stones, under ground. Intermixed them with a lower layer of Peach and plum Stones— John found several of the small white worms at the roots of the young Peach trees; and saw the little striped Squirrel which has preyed upon my Indian Corn. I planted also with Peach and Plum Stones and Woodhouse Apple seeds a division of the Stony-barren. Read 15 Sections of the first Book of Cicero’s Treatise de Diviniatione. This is in the form of a conversation between his brother Quintus and himself at his Tusculan Villa. The exposition of the doctrine is made by Quintus, who professes his belief in divination, which was rather a subject of ridicule among the Romans of that time—
11. V. Saturday.

My health has improved, and my labour in the garden and nursery gives me sufficient exercise: perhaps they may teach me the lesson of moderation. I planted this morning an alternate row of Peach and Plum-stones, at the central division of the Nursery on the West side: with Apple and Bass-wood seeds, black Currants, and one fox grape. This was the spot where in 1827 a row of English Oak Acorns was planted; which came up well, but perished the first winter— There is little but stones and gravel for soil— I now planted my seeds and Stones, between two layers of Garden Mould which I transferred from the Garden to the Trench— Gathered the last Horse Plums; three only upon a tree which had been neglected— They ripen from the 15th. of August to the 1st. of September.— George Hardwick was here and I promised to call and look at the house in which he lives next Monday— Spear brought a third load of Oak-wood; and asked me to go to Mount Wollaston, and select a spot for an Orchard this afternoon, which I did. Rode down with my Son John, and inspected the three Acres of Salt marsh which Spear purchased for me last Winter. Ascertained its boundaries; and viewed a fine grove of Oaks, Black White and Grey, and of spurious Shag-bark Walnuts— Few Acorns; no true Shagbarks, and numberless Multitudes of Musquitoes. I determined on taking up for the Orchard a Pasture at the South side of Mount Wollaston itself, which Spear is to stake out and prepare for ploughing up— I had a Letter from Charles, who says that Mr Brooks recommends that the Trees to be planted for an Orchard, should be taken up in the Autumn, kept over winter and planted in the Spring— This is the new system of Mr Phinney, who has promulgated it by a paper in the New-England Farmer. Spear shewed me a place, where he thinks the tide will make a breach into the adjoining land, and spoil his Spring of water if not diked out— Also his Spring which he has surrounded with willows; which he wishes also to do with the
Spring behind his house— I viewed also the place where Henry Hardwick wishes to purchase about a quarter of an Acre adjoining a lot of one Acre which he now owns— But this one Acre belonged originally to my farm, and was cabbaged out of it many years ago; no one now knows how or when— Evening unoccupied.
12. IV:45. Sunday.

Visited the Nursery— The vegetation is beginning to decay— The Horse Chestnuts are the first Trees that shed their leaves—which have already been for some time scorched by the Sun— Dr Holbrook was here this morning to visit the mother and child, both of whom are as well as prayers could ask— Heard MrWhitman said to be of Waltham; from Philippians 4:4 “Rejoice in The Lord alway”—and from John 14.2. “In my father’s House, are many mansions: if it were not so, I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you. 3. And if I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again, and receive you unto myself; that where I am, there ye may be also.” The argument upon the morning text reminded me of much that I have been recently reading in Cicero—particularly in the Treatise de Finibus and the Tusculans. The doctrine of the Stoics was Rejoice always— In pain, in poverty, in affliction in Death, we are still to rejoice— So say the Stoics— So says, more doubtingly Cicero—and so says Saint Paul. But for this Conquest over the weakness of the flesh, the Greek Philosophers gave no preceptive means— They said it was the reward of wisdom— The attribute of the wise man— Mr Whitman says that the means of fulfilling the precept, given by the Apostle are furnished by the Religion which he preached— That the Christian religion alone, teaches and enables us to rejoice always; and that is true—but Shakespear as truly says there was never yet Philosopher, who could endure the toothache patiently; and sincere and ardent Christians may be more successful in learning resignation in affliction than joy— The afternoon Sermon was upon the certainty of a future state— Louisa C. Smith dined with us; and towards Evening I rode with Mrs Adams and Louisa round the Gulliver’s brook Square.
13. V. Monday

I planted the last row of Peach and Plum stones, Apple-seeds, whole Pears and Cores, Bass wood seeds and black Currants in the Stony-barren border from the centre to the gate of the Nursery, on the Eastern side— I have taken out many large stones to the depth of a foot or more under ground from this border— One this day required the aid of a Crow bar to bring it up; and I have supplied their places in the trenches with manure of mould from the garden— I place some of these large Stones round the roots of the young peach trees as an experiment to protect them from the worms— Steeped a quantity of fox grapes in a bottle of New-England Rum— Had a morning visit from Joseph Blunt of New-York, who dined with us— John rode with him to the Railway. I went with Mrs Adams and Louisa to Weymouth— In the evening I finished the first and began the second book of Cicero de Divinatione— One of the most amusing, though not the most philosophical of his writings. The primary position of the book is, that divination is a reality and not a mere creature of imagination or an imposture— Cicero was not willing to maintain this position himself and has therefore assigned the task to his brother Quintus; who professes sincerely to believe in divination. Of this he contends there are two kinds—one natural; the other artificial. The natural a prophetic delirium or frenzy, like that of Cassandra— The other taught scientifically— An Art practiced by Augur’s and Aruspices—and of which the indications were in the flight of birds, the feeding of chickens and the entrails of sacrificed victims— The first of his arguments is that the question of divination is in fact the question of the existence of Gods, or of their taking an interest in human Affairs— To deny the one, he insists is to deny the other— For if there be Gods, and they take any concern in the affairs of men, they necessarily must give occasional
preintimations of their will to those who enjoy their favour. His second argument is derived from the testimony of all nations, universally concurring in the assertion of predictions verified; and finally he repeats with a gravity consummately ludicrous, all the absurd and silly tales, which the Greeks and Romans had heaped up in the course of seven or eight centuries, all of which he declares himself fully to believe— He admits that vaticination is very often at fault, and that the event almost always gives the lie to the prophecy; but this he thinks furnishes no decisive objection to the art, any more than the fatal termination of diseases disproves the art or skill of the physician. If the prediction is sometimes fulfilled that sufficiently demonstrates the art of divination— He quotes verses from his brothers translation of Aratus, and from the Latin Poets, Ennius, Accius and Pacuvius— The subject becomes too ridiculous when he attempts to establish a natural connection between the course of Events, and the chickens, the birds, the male crow at the right hand, and the female at the left, and the entrails of slaughtered oxen— Returning from Weymouth I stopped at the foot of Penn’s Hill and discussed with Joseph Hardwick the repairs necessary upon the old family mansion. Another neighbour called on me to repair the partition fence of the Quincy Meadow, and I met Deacon Spear, whom I requested to call upon me to make arrangements for the repair of the old House, and for the Sale of wood in standing lots—
14. V. Tuesday.

My brother’s Son Joseph came to enquire for Letters, and said he had been to Milton for Dr Holbrook to visit his mother, who is ill with a sore throat. Dr. Holbrook himself was afterwards here— My wife went after dinner to see Mrs T. B. Adams who was confined to her bed, as was her niece Susan Harrod. Abby too has the sore throat and they are apprehensive of an Epidemic— Visit in the afternoon from Mr John Connell of Philadelphia, with his Son Martin— They have been with Mrs Connell at the Saratoga, Ballstown, and Lebanon Springs— Travelling for recreation, and to dull the edge of affliction, at the loss of two children within the last six months— I had intended to ride this afternoon to Roxbury and visit Genl Dearborn, but was prevented by the call of Mr Connell, and a drizzling Northeastern breeze— In the Nursery I planted a second cross row, from the centre Eastward, with Peach stones, Pear Cores, black Currants, Apple and Bass wood seeds. On the other side—a Horse Chesnut at each end of the central cross row, to serve as stakes hereafter— The vegetation of every thing but weeds has ceased, and they grow with rank luxuriance. The Season has been peculiarly favourable to the growth of trees, and all my young ones that had survived the last Winter, are thriving except the Peach trees, which seem doomed to perish with the worm at the root— I wrote part of this Evening; and read the Accounts from France— The king has formally abdicated the Crown; and after a fruitless attempt to obtain it for the Duke of Bordeaux, has capitulated to the Commissioners sent to him by the Legislative Chambers, and was moving to Cherbourg to embark; some accounts say for the United States— The Duke of Orleans is Lieutenant General of the Kingdom, and La Fayette Commander General of the National Guards. The Revolution was accomplished in the space of a weeks— The arbitrary Edicts of the king were issued on the 26th of July— The first movement of popular resistance on the 27th—the king fled on the 29th. and his definitive abdication was on the 3d. of August— The Duke of Orleans will probably be the king for some time— But times of turbulence, are apparently recommencing in Europe, and Liberty and kings are still to grapple with each other.
15. V. Wednesday.

After a very heavy rain in the Night, this day was fair and warm— My brother was here; and spoke of leasing the Penny-ferry Saltmarsh— It was his birth day, and he completed his fifty eighth year. I planted a row of peaches, cherries, plum-stones, Apple seeds and Pear Cores at different depths at the entrance of the Nursery, Westward from the Alley to the Apple tree near the Wall. That the young trees, may have the shade of the tree for protection, from the Sun— I found worms at the roots of several of my peach trees. The best preserved is that which I surrounded last Summer with Stones. Farrar killed the ground Squirrel which has been depredating upon the patch of Nursery Corn— About the size of a large rat he has devoured almost the whole of 20 Hills of Corn; and has commenced an attack upon the Cabbages— After dinner I rambled over the hills, and inspected many of the growing trees— There are several varieties of the hickory walnut; some of which are not given by Michaux— One is the spurious Shell-bark; a nut half way between that and the pignut— There is a wood of Buttons, Walnuts and Junipers growing spontaneously on the South declivity of the Hill, and which is already valuable, promising to be more so. I found some of the Walnuts fallen from the Trees; but all the Pignuts which I brought home, floated in water, and the nuts were withered or unsound. I propose to plant numbers of the Shellbark, and of the pignuts separately; to observe whether they will each produce its kind— I gathered two Pears of the wild stock, which remained on the tree. There I propose also to plant— And I gathered berries of a tree unknown to me— The wild cherries on the large tree are not yet ripe— I had received an invitation from the Committee of Arrangements for the second Centennial celebration of the settlement of Boston, the day after to-morrow, to a public dinner at Faneuil Hall—but the Committee give notice in the newspaper of this day that there will be no such dinner, it having been found that the Citizens of Boston prefer dining at home.
16. V. Thursday.

I was nearly three hours in my Nursery this Morning—great part of the Time digging a Trench along by the western Wall, over the Stony-barren line— Planted a third short row of Pears, Plum and Cherry-stones, Apple seeds and Ashpods, at different depths, from the alley westward to the Apple tree, at the left hand after entering by the gate. For this year, I pay little attention to the quality of my seeds; being specially bent upon raising from the seed and stone, as many trees and as great a variety of them as possible— Mrs Hall, Louisa C. Smith and Mrs Lucy Dawes were here before dinner, and at half past four this afternoon my Son John left us to return to Washington. John Kirke went with him to Dedham, where he is to take the Stage to-morrow for Providence as it passes— He goes to resume his business; having spent nearly three Months of the Summer with us; and having been blest while here, with the birth of a second daughter. He agreed with me that she should be baptized here, and told me the name he proposed to give her— I walked before the Evening round through Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s grounds from the Boston road to the bathing wharf; which for this Season I had deserted— I inspected all his Oak and Walnut trees; only two or three of which bear any fruit. My brothers Son Joseph Harrod came, and asked to go with me to Boston tomorrow; to which I consented— I received this day a Notice from the Committee of Arrangements that there will be no dinner to-morrow at Faneuil Hall— I received also
from Mr Frothingham, a copy of his centennial Sermon upon the two hundredth anniversary of the formation of the first Church in Boston, of which he is the Minister— I had urged Mr Frothingham to preach this discourse; but the task appears to have been irksome to him, and his views of the subject differ much from mine— I had also a Letter from Luigi Persico, proposing to make me a present of my Bust in marble.
17. IV:30— Friday.

Second centennial celebration of the Settlement of Boston— I went to the City, taking my brother’s Son Joseph Harrod with me— Called first at Charles’s Office, but he passed the day at Medford. I stopped at my old friend Joseph Hall’s— Mrs Hall is dangerously ill, with a pulmonary disease. At nine I went to the Senate Chamber in the State-House, where the City Government and others were assembled for the procession— General William Sullivan was the Chief Marshal of the day— He and the Mayor H. G. Otis and Coll. T. H. Perkins came and offered me their hands, and their salutation was accepted— Numbers of others of my old acquaintance were more cordial. A place had been assigned to me by name in the processions and two of the Marshals were assigned to me, for an escort. The procession moved about ten; passed through the Common, down Tremont Court, and State Streets to the head of long wharf, then returned through State Street, and the old Cornhill, to the Old South Meeting House where after a Prayer by the Minister of the Church Mr Wisner, and the 100th. Psalm partly sung by a large choir to the tune of Old Hundred, an Oration was delivered by Josiah Quincy, President of Harvard University, worthy of the subject and received with universal approbation. There was then performed to the tune of God save the King an Hymn by Mr Pierpont— And precisely at the moment when they were singing as part of a Stanza [“]Ye temples, that to God, Rise where our fathers trod, Guard well your trust,” a bench broke down, a Panic seized many of the persons in the western upper gallery, that it was giving way, and there was a momentary alarm and great rush to the door, but it subsided without injury to any one— The Choir resumed their hymn— It was followed by a Poem, delivered by Charles Sprague— Very short, and not very good. In irregular verse, poorly spoken, and containing more about Indian Savages, and the recent Revolution in France and General La Fayette, than about the Settlement of Boston, or the Pilgrim Fathers— After Handel’s Hallelujah Chorus, the Benediction was pronounced by Mr Frothingham; Minister of the first Church—and the procession returned to the State House; whence they dispersed— I went with Mr Silsbee to the Tremont House: and dined with him at the Lady’s common Table. His daughter was there—Mr and Mrs Crowninshield, and their two daughters—Mr and Mrs. Connell and their Son; and a number more. After dinner Mr Richard Derby came, sat down at the Table— Refused to drink wine and then took a glass alone; asked Crowninshield for a pinch of snuff, and then sent to the barroom for a little snuff in a paper, and told how Mrs Humphreys had at the age of 55 thrown herself and a fortune of two hundred and fifty thousand dollars away upon a Polish Waterloo Colonel, and spurious Count Walawsky. I soon withdrew, and called at Mrs Dexter’s house, but she was gone to Pittsfield. I thence went and passed an hour at Mr James H. Foster’s. Viewed the fireworks in the Common, and made a short appearance at Lieutt. Governor Thomas L Winthrop’s Evening party, where I met again some of the persons I had seen in the day— Mr. Martin, one of the members of the House of Representatives from South Carolina in Congress; Mr Krehmer of the Russian Legation, Everetts, Bulfinch’s, Coolidge’s, Crowninshield’s, Silsbee’s, and
some whom I did not know. There was lamentation upon the issue of the recent elections in the State of Maine, and exultation at that in the City of Charleston S. Carolina a damper to the nullification doctrine— Mr Winthrop’s Son asked me to select a Lady to lead in to supper, but I excused myself from the necessity of returning to Quincy this Evening. I took up Joseph at his Uncle Phineas Foster’s— The Town Clock struck ten, as we were driving through the Streets, and at a quarter past eleven we got home— Joseph remains here for the Night— Mr Joseph Richardson, the Representative in Congress from Plymouth District, of which Quincy forms a part, and Mr John B. Davis said they wished to converse with me, and would call upon me to-morrow— Edward Everett asked me if he might publish a Letter which I wrote him a few days since, in answer to some inquiries from him relating to the Negotiation of the Treaty with the Porte: I thought best it should not be published— He asked me what I said of going to Congress; I told him I had nothing to say about it— Ten or twelve days since appeared in the Boston Courier a paragraph, proposing that the People of the Plymouth District should elect me as their Representative to the next Congress— As the Editor of the Paper has been uniformly hostile to me, I supposed this nomination was made with the same Spirit, and did not imagine it was seriously thought of by any one— It was to this nomination however that Everett alluded; and he told me that Mr Richardson declined a re-election—
18. V:30. Saturday.

There was a frost last Night, and the Thermometer in my Library was this morning at 50. The Sun raised it in the course of the day to 60, but towards Evening it fell again— I prepared for making a fire, but make a point of postponing it till the day of the Equinox— After breakfast I took two hours of labour in my Nursery, and planted my Stony barren row under the western Wall— The spot is the best sheltered from the frigid Northwest winds of any part of the enclosure; but is exposed to the Sun and to the East winds— I planted whole Pears; 4. Woodhouse Apples, Fox-grapes, cherries, Mazzard and wild—one Peach-Plum stones and Ash pods; at different depths, one between two layers of mould from the garden, the other on the top of the second— I was called in to the house to Mr John B. Davis, who came to make inquiries concerning the character of Mr Connell. Mr Davis has an interest in a claim upon the French Government, of those which Connell is endeavouring to obtain from the Claimants an authority to the Government of the United States to settle by compromise. I told Mr Davis that with regard to the expediency of giving the authority for the Settlement, I had nothing to say; but I could give unqualified testimony to the character of Mr Connell, both for capacity and integrity— While Davis was here, Mr Richardson came; and Davis said he had seen in the newspaper that he declined a re-election to the next Congress. He said it was a determination long since taken by him— That he thought it due to the people of his Congregation at Hingham; who had been exceedingly reluctant at his going even to the present Congress; and he said he came purposely to inquire of me, if I would serve, if elected as a member for the District. I said I had observed in a paper, the Editor of which without any cause known to me, had invariably been hostile to me, a nomination to that effect, about ten days since— From whom the nomination came I knew not; but had believed it made, in no friendly Spirit towards me.— I had not supposed it serious; or that any person had a thought of holding me up for that election— Mr Richardson said that if I would serve he believed the election could be carried; by a large majority—as the Old Colony Memorial and the Hingham Gazette the only Newspapers printed in the District, and another paper published in the adjoining District, and taken by some of his
constituents, would support the nomination—but if I should decline, it was not probable that the District would unite upon any other person, and there would be no election. He then said he thought that the service in the House of Representatives of an Ex-President of the United States instead of degrading the individual, would elevate the Representative Character— I said I had in that respect no scruple whatever— No person could be degraded by serving the People as a Representative in Congress— Nor in my opinion would an Ex-President of the United States be degraded by serving as a Selectman of his town if elected thereto by the People— But age and infirmity had their privileges and their disqualifications. I had not the slightest desire to be elected to Congress—and could not consent to be a candidate for Election— I knew not how the Election would turn; and if chosen it might depend upon Circumstances whether I should deem it my duty to serve or to decline— The state of my health—the degree of opposition to the choice, the character of the candidate in opposition might each or all contribute to my determination— Mr Richardson said this was sufficient and he would go to work. He desired Mr Davis to consider as secret and confidential what had passed here, which he promised— After dinner I rode with Mrs Adams to the Milliner’s at Weymouth— Saw there Matthew Pratt, an old man who formerly lived several years on my father’s place at the foot of Penn’s Hill— Gathered a few Acorns from a White Oak Tree on the summit of Penn’s Hill—which I propose to plant, and call Cap white Oak— Evening so cold that I could not write.
19. V:15. Sunday.

Short visit to my Garden and Nursery. Heard Mr Flint of Cohasset, morning, from Psalm 66.13— I will pay thee my vows, 14. Which my lips have uttered, and my mouth hath spoken, when I was in trouble— Afternoon from Proverbs 22.6. “Train up a Child in the way he should go; and when he is old, he will not depart from it.” Two most impressive texts—the latter so often handled as to have become a common place— The former seldom noticed, but containing a moral lesson, not less important— The obligation of Christians to perform the promises and fulfil the Resolutions made when in trouble is a copious subject for introduction and reproof. Mr Flint treated it with plain good sense, but his elocution is so languid and drawling that it does great injustice to his composition. His afternoon discourse, upon the education of children might have been improved by the perusal of Tillotson’s Sermons on the same Subject. Mr Flint dined with us. After the second Service, I rode with Mrs Adams over Milton Hill into Dorchester, returning by the upper bridge over the Neponset— I could not write in my chamber; and read in the dining room below, where we had a fire. I finished reading the second Book de Divinatione— It is occupied entirely by Marcus Cicero himself, who declares his total disbelief in Divination: and refutes the Arguments and ridicules the authorities, and examples cited by Quintus in favour of it— He cautiously disclaimed any intention to interfere with the Religion of the Country— He therefore agrees and urges that the Auguries and Aruspications should be continued; for the preservation and prosperity of the Republic— But he says as they are alone, and as the principles of the Academic philosophy which he approved were rather to raise than absolve doubts; he assures him that he believes nothing in Divination— He takes the whole discourse of Quintus to pieces, rejects with scorn the idea, that the entrails of beasts the flight of birds or the feeding of chickens should have any connection whatever with the Fortunes of individuals,
and argues with great acuteness and irresistible cogency against the possibility of any positive foresight of Events— He leaves nothing for human reason to reply— In the 30th. Section he gives an extract of about 30 lines from Homers Iliad, in Latin Hexameter verse of his own composition— They are from the second Book of the Iliad V. 299–333. and in Pope’s Translation V. 364–397.— In the 56th. Section he cites the double meaning Oracles, delivered to Croesus, and to Pyrrhus: and in the 58th. he remarks that there is no absurdity so great but it has been affirmed by some philosopher— I read also three Sections of the Book de Fato—
20. IV:15. Monday.

Fahrenheit at 51 this morning. Frosts at Night— The Sun raised the Thermometer in the course of the day to 60; but in the Evening it fell again to 55— We have fire in the dining room but I make none yet in my Library— I warmed myself after breakfast by spading in the Nursery— My ground is too narrow for my projects of plantation— I plucked up the stalks of my twenty hills of Missouri Corn, eaten up by the ground Squirrels, and commenced a trench from the lower part of the Nursery to the old Apple-tree near the centre— I was called in to Deacon Spear, and therefore planted nothing this day. I consulted with the Deacon, about leasing for the next year, my Penn’s valley houses and Lands— We looked over the plans, and he advised me to lease the houses with small parcels of land separately and the lots by themselves— I determined to have the valley farm resurveyed to ascertain whether a mistake was made by Mr Humphreys in his Survey of last year: and to divide it into small lots for leasing— Mr Spear said he should see Mr Humphreys in two or three days, and would ask him to call upon me— Henry Hardwick came to ask again about the quarter of an Acre of Saltmarsh, at the Mount Wollaston farm which he wished to purchase of me— I told him I had seen it, but could not conveniently dispose of it— I rode this afternoon with my wife to Weymouth— As we were returning, stopp’d at the White Oak tree in Goose pasture at the summit of Penn’s Hill— Gathered about fifty of the Acorns, which are ripe— I went into the lot, to see if it might be broken up for a plantation of Oaks—but it is almost all Rock. It will scarcely bear trees— Yet I found in it a Rock Chesnut Oak, from which I picked three fine Acorns, not ripe. While we were out Mr D. A. Hall of Washington, and George S. Bulfinch called at my house— Mrs Holley came to live with us as Cook, and Lucretia Spear, as Nursery Maid for Louisa. Unable to write, for the cold, I passed the Evening in the dining-room—finished reading the Book de Fato, and read five Sections of the first de Legibus— The book de Fato is a fragment; the subject is a sequel to the Treatise upon divination, but is separated altogether from it— In the Book de Fato, Cicero himself is the expounder, at the request of Hirtius, then designated Consul; who had come to the Puteolan Villa, to consult with Cicero upon public affairs after the Death of Julius Caesar: and who desired to enliven the gloomy topic of political contention, by the discussion of philosophical enquiries— The inextricable tangle of Fate and Free-will, perplexes Cicero as it must every thinking mind to the end of Time— The Stoics were Fatalists. the Academics and Cicero with them insisted upon the Freedom of the Will; and he urges with energy that fatalism takes away all discrimination between virtue and vice—right and wrong.
21. V. Tuesday.

Changed our Bedchamber last Night— Bridget M’Donough and Elizabeth Caldwell, Cook and Nursery-maid returned to Boston, where Charles from this day resumes his City residence— Fahrenheit at 54. raised by the Sun to 64. and at Evening fell to 56. In the Nursery, spading along the Western Wall, from the Squirrel corn patch to the old Apple tree. Planted a small row, on the Stony-barren line, towards the Gate— Cap white Oak Acorns, Apple-seeds, Ash pods, Cherries, Mazzard and wild Peach, Pear and grape.

I was called from the Nursery to receive the visit of a Mr Van Zandt of Albany, who brought a Letter of introduction from Judge Ambrose Spencer— A boy, son of Mr I. P. Thorndike was with him— Mr Benjamin Bass came to renew a proposal for exchanging land with me. I walked over the Hill with him and inspected the ground, with Mr Withington’s plan reduced last Fall, by W. C. Greenleaf— I found it exceedingly convenient. Mr Bass’s offer was to exchange from 15 to 20 Acres of barren, and nearly bare hill side, for an equal quantity of the most fertile spot on my farm; well garnished with thriving Walnut trees and other valuable wood— He had also much argument to prove that his land was quite as good as mine: When I declined the exchange, he urged me with importunity to let him have so much of my land as would supply his lot with an inexhaustible spring of water, of which he has none— He also intimated a disposition to sell the whole of his lot. Before returning home I visited my walnut trees, and found the boys had been after the nuts already—but none of them are ripe— While I was gone out Mr John Parker was here with a friend of his, and Mr B. Gorham, the Representative in Congress from Boston; who declines a re-election. In the afternoon I rode with my wife to Milton and we gathered some elder berries, too late in the Season by a fortnight— My brother’s wife was here with her, daughter Elizabeth; just returned from her visit to Portland and Haverhill. Lucretia Spear takes the place of Elizabeth Caldwell, as Louisa’s Nurse, and Mrs Holley, Bridget’s place as Cook— Letters from my Son John at New-York, and from Jos. Gales junr. at Washington—
22. III.45. Wednesday.

Fahrenheit yet at 55. but I postpone the fire in the Library. Spaded the last division of Stony-barren under the western Wall— Planted 7. Cap white Oak Acorns— Apple-seeds. Ashpods— Wild Cherries, Pear Cores, and Peaches— Dug out large stones from the trench; filled their places with mould from the garden. Labour thoroughly wearisome—and wholsome— Deacon Spear came and informed me that he had seen Mr Humphreys, who if the weather should be fair will come to resurvey the Penn’s Valley farm next Monday. The Deacon spoke of the Election for the House of Representatives to come on the first Monday in November, and asked me if I considered myself an Inhabitant of Quincy. I said certainly— If not an inhabitant of Quincy, I was an inhabitant of no where— He said that was all he wished to know: but he nevertheless did give some further hints, that there were persons very desirous of electing me to Congress, and others equally anxious to prevent it. He said the Jackson men would do every thing to defeat the choice, and that they included all the most violent men of both the parties; federal and democratic— He said there would be a District Convention soon to fix upon the person to be chosen— That he had formerly attended those Meetings; but it was rather hard for Quincy to have to send so far— I asked how it happened that Quincy had been cast into the Plymouth District for Elections to Congress— He said he attributed it to Mr. Thomas Greenleaf who was in the Council when the thing was done; and the object of it was to make Plymouth a certainly federal district but now, what with antimasonic and Jackson men, parties were all broken up, and no one could tell what any man was— My tenant of Mount Woolaston Alpheus Spear was here; and spoke of the orchard which I propose to plant there— I told him I should come down and
view the ground someday this week or the next— Mr M’Allister paid me a short morning visit— Afternoon ride with my wife to Braintree; gathering Elderberries on the way— The Newspaper of this day announces the election of the Duke of Orleans, by the Legislative Chambers as King of France; and his acceptance of the crown—
23. III.45 Thursday.

The weather has moderated almost to the temperature of Summer. I wake in the morning at three and rise before four—to little purpose. Spaded over the Corn patch, where the 20 hills were devoured by the ground Squirrels. S. Farrar has shot three of them, fat as feasted Capons, and there are others now devouring the Cabbages— I dug one trench from West to East, and planted a row from the Stony-barren centre to the pumice young Apple trees—with Cap white Oak Acorns, Apple-seeds, Ashpods: wild cherries, Horse Chesnuts, Peaches and Stones, Pear-seeds and Cores, and the unknown berries. My brother and his daughter Abby were here— He mentioned that Mr Peyton Gay had changed his plan of settling in the West; and now proposed going to France and requested a Letter of Introduction from me to General La Fayette. My brother had also a Letter from his Son Thomas, and I had one with an Order on the Cashier of U.S. Branch Bank Boston, for 3000 dollars which he wishes me to invest for him in funds yielding interest— The Lieutt. is ordered with his company to a station on the Cherokee Lands in the State of Georgia. Abby dined with us— I received visits from Mr Hutchinson Consul of the United States at Lisbon, accompanied by a Mr Morse— Alpheus Spear came to request me to go to the Mount Wollaston farm, this afternoon which I did— I fixed for an Orchard upon a spot adjoining the garden, Westward of the House—on the Southern side of the Mount. There are 23. Rods or 379 1/2 feet in a line between the garden fence and a rail-fence now there at the road, in which there is however an Angle— We measured 540 feet from South to North, from the Road along the line of the Garden fence as it stands, then the same distance from East to West to the standing rail-fence— Then the same measure along the rail fence from North to South to the road—but there is what Spear calls a heater piece on the western line as well as upon the road— I then made my Estimates with Spear and his brother who is a more acute accountant— Three sides of rail fence to make 32 3/4 Rods each 146 Posts 580 Rails— They earnestly recommended Chesnut Posts instead of Cedar, as lasting much longer, and they had a lot of Chesnut Posts stuck in the Salt marsh water, for seasoning; which they thought they could let me have—price from 20 to 25 Cents a Post— The rails cost 6 dollars a hundred— The Spears advise that the trees should be planted 2 rods or 33 feet apart—16 trees in the long line, 224 trees in the whole— I inspected also the ridge of Mount Wollaston with a wish to cover it with fine Oaks; and a fear that it will prove impracticable— Passed the Evening in my chamber, writing and reading.
24. IV. Friday— Fahrenheit 76.

Summer heat— The Sun expelled me from the Nursery, an hour before my time— Planted a double row from West to East; at the bottom of the Nursery to the left hand; on the Squirrel, Corn-patch—Horse-Chesnuts—1 Shell bark Walnut. 1. Rock Chesnut Oak Acorn—Apple-seeds, Pear Cores; Peaches and Stones. Ashpods, and 1 grape— The maturity of my seeds outstrips my preparation of ground— On the Evening when I gathered my Cap White Oak Acorns, I dropped them into a tumbler of Water, and they all sank like lead— The next Morning I took them out of the Water, and without
wiping them, put them into a broken footed Rhenish wine glass. This morning I found four or five of them had sprouted— I planted two of them in one of my Summer-house cellar blue boxes; and one in the other— In the course of the day a number more of my Cap Acorns sprouted— My brother dined with us, and I had an afternoon visit from Mr Sheppard from Boston— Wrote a Note by him to Charles. Walked across the Hills observing the maturation of Shellbarks, pignuts and the unknown berry; of all which I gathered a few.— The Shellbarks are so nearly ripe that the boys have already been at the trees— I called at Mr Peter Whitney’s, and asked if he should preach at home next Sunday— He said he should— I told him I proposed presenting my Son John’s infant daughter for baptism— Spent the Evening in my chamber, writing— Answered this morning a Letter from William Plumer— Received one from his Son and one from Charles Miner, of West-Chester, Pennsylvania. A Mr Holbrook a tax collector for Braintree, brought me this Morning a tax-bill, of near 3 dollars, for Land in Braintree, valued in the Assessment at 700 dollars— I asked him where and what the Land was—he did not know— I told him if he could find it in Braintree I would readily pay the tax, but that last year it could not be found; and the tax was remitted— He had also the tax for the heirs of Norton Quincy, which from 25 Cents last year had now swollen to 1. dollar 35 Cents— I referred him for information concerning this to my brother.
25. IV. Saturday.

Planted in the Nursery a Row from West to East in the line of the young Elm. 13 Cap white Oak Acorns, all sprouted. Horse Chesnuts, Apple seeds, Ashpods, Cherries, Peaches, Plum stones—Pear Cores, Buttons and 2 berries of the Unknown— Morning visit from Mr West, the exhibiter of his father’s Picture of Christ rejected. Nathaniel Amory, Isaac P. Davis and Alexander H. Everett— Much conversation upon the recent French Revolution, the hereditary monarchy, exclusively in the male line; and the proposed abolition of the hereditary house of Peers— Unquiet times in prospect, for France and for all Europe— Mr Davis invited me to dine with him next Saturday; and said he would ask his brother the Judge to meet me— I accepted his invitation— Rode after dinner with Mrs Adams to Braintree— Visit afterwards from Mr Bailey, who is yet undetermined whether to decline a re-election to Congress from the Norfolk District or not— He had expected that General Dearborn would be elected in his place; but he now believed the General was not heartily enough Anti-masonic to carry the Election— Mr Mann will also be one of the prominent Candidates, and there were some doubts of the correctness of his principles— Mr Bailey spoke of the nomination which first appeared in the Boston Courier of me, to represent the Plymouth District in the next Congress. Where and with whom, and in what motive this project originated is yet a mystery; but it has taken root in the District, and I received this morning the Hingham Gazette of yesterday, in which my name is proposed in an Editorial Article and in two Communications— Mr Bailey said he had been asked by several persons whether I would accept the Office if elected; and enquired whether he might answer that question if again put to him as it certainly would be— I said I could not answer it myself— To say that I would accept, would be so near to asking for a vote, that I did not feel disposed to go so far— I wished the People to act spontaneously; at their own discretion. If they
should elect me, whether I could serve them might depend upon circumstances. The meeting of the Congress would not be till December of the next year. What the state of things might then be I could not foresee. If I should finally decline, I would give notice of it to the People of the District in Season to enable them to agree upon another person, to take the place as effectually as they could now— Mr Bailey said there was no prospect that they could now agree upon a Candidate, or that a choice would be effected, if I should decline— My son John’s eldest child Louisa, was unwell yesterday and more so all this day. I finished reading Cicero de Legibus.
26. IV. Sunday.

Heavy Rain in the Night and all this morning till noon, after which it subsided. I rode to Meeting this Morning. Heard Mr Whitney; from Isaiah 57.20. [“]But the wicked are like the troubled Sea, when it cannot rest, whose waters cast up mire and dirt— 21. There is no Peace, saith my God, to the wicked.” The necessary and inevitable connection between wickedness and punishment, is the doctrine of this text—a Sound and salutary doctrine— Sermon very short— The afternoon text was from Ephesians 6.13. “Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand.”— Before the afternoon service, my Son John’s infant daughter was baptised by Mr Whitney by the name of Georgiana Frances— Mrs Nowland held the Child as Nurse, and the father being absent, I presented it for baptism— The Grandmother was also present, but the mother not sufficiently recovered to leave her chamber— Mrs Nowland and my dear wife left the house and returned home immediately after the Christening. Coll. Quincy was here this Evening— John’s eldest child has a sore throat, and ulcerated mouth, and is apparently breeding two double teeth—distressingly ill this Evening— I read 15 Sections of the first Book de Officiis— The books de Legibus are incomplete, and were probably left unfinished by their author— In the philosophical Treatises he has taken Plato for his model, and after composing a work de Republica followed it up by a proposed philosophical dissertation upon Laws. It is in the form of a Dialogue between Atticus, Quintus Cicero and Marcus himself. There is no preamble, as there is to all the other philosophical works, but the Dialogue commences abruptly by a remark of Atticus, supposed to be walking with the two Cicero’s in a grove at Arpinum— Atticus points to an Oak, which he thinks the same which had been noticed by Cicero in a Poem upon Marius— Whether this form of introducing the subject was intentional, or whether the Proem was to have been prefixed, when the work should be completed is uncertain, but the introductions to the other philosophical works are all so much alike, that this entrament once upon the main theme of the discourse, forms a pleasing variety more acceptable to present readers, than would have been another lamentation upon the ruin of the Republic, and another narrative of the authors passion for philosophical disquisitions— In the conversation preceding the subject of the dialogue, Quintus urges his brother to write a History, upon which Marcus observes that it would require more preparation and leisure time than he has worked to bestow, and he adds some judicious remarks upon the principles applicable to the composition of History. Atticus then intimates a wish to hear his friend discourse upon Law; to which he assents, and declares it a subject worthy of the highest powers of human contemplation—for be assured, says he, that there is no topic of discourse among men, better suited to display the natural attributes of man, the extent and excellence of his mental powers, the ends and purposes of pursuit and action for which we were born, the causes and objects of human association, from which the fountain of Laws, and of their Administration is to be discovered.
This is the foundation of the subsequent Discourse; the first Book of which consists of general Considerations upon the nature of Law, as the result of the utmost energies of wisdom: and ultimately terminating in the operation of divine wisdom—the authority which commands or forbids human Action— The second book treats of the Laws and Ministers of religion, and the third of those relating to the Magistracy, and to the Administration of the Government— At the close of this he promises to take up in the next Book the Law of Natures, and the proper Roman Law— The Assassin Ruffians of Mark Antony have robb’d the world of that Treasure.
27. IV:15. Monday.

We had a deeply disturbed night with John’s eldest child Louisa; whose cries from the pain she suffers are almost incessant, and heart rending— Dr Holbrook was here this morning, and thought her illness not dangerous— She was quiet nearly the whole day, but as Evening came on was again in severe and unintermitting pain— Mr Humphreys the Surveyor from Weymouth came at 8 this morning, and we resurveyed the Penn’s Valley Farm; the survey of the last year having fallen several Acres short of what purported to be contained in my father’s deed to me of August 1803. and of the previous conveyances to him— We now undertook to mark separately 1. The lot of 9 1/2 or 10 Acres, conveyed to my Grandfather by Billings in 1744. and given in my Grandfather’s will to my father. 2. The Homestead of 35 Acres, given by my Grandfather’s Will to my Uncle Peter B. Adams, and by him conveyed to my father in 1774. 3. The lot of 46. Acres, conveyed by W and S. Vesey to my father in February 1788. And 4. The lot of 7. Acres conveyed by Moses and Huldah Babcock to my father 2. May 1783. These four parcels constitute the Estate, included in one survey last year.— I supposed until this day that there was included in it also 16 1/2 Acres. conveyed in April 1762 by Nathaniel Belcher to my father, my uncle Peter and Joseph Field; but I now found that this was part of another Survey; and that the Land is South of Joseph Field’s land adjoining mine— Joseph Field, now 81 years of age, and son of the man to whom the joint conveyance was made, now shewed me other papers, connected with this transaction; among which a Quit-claim deed, dated 11. April 1764—from my father, and my uncle Peter, of 5 1/2 Acres of the 16 1/2 to Joseph Field his father— This explanation reduces the possible error of Mr Humphreys’s last year’s survey to about 7. Acres; precisely the quantity of the grant from the Babcock’s— In this day’s Survey, William Spear and Salmon Farrar were with us—carrying the chain and sticks— Deacon Daniel Spear joined us twice for half an hour each time— We did not measure round on the swampy fresh meadows adjoining upon Ebenezer and Josiah Adams: the water being so high after the heavy rain of yesterday that the passages were nearly impracticable— I gathered about a pint of Acorns of Black, White, and Chesnut Oaks, in what I call the Druid Plains behind the Old Brook— The White Oak Acorns are ripe—many fallen, and some sprouting on the Tree— The Chesnut Oak Acorns are ripening and the black still unripe— The finest white are from an old tree which was already a large one when I was a boy, and which is one of the first objects of my remembrance. I shall call them therefore Druid, and mark the Acorns which I shall plant from them, for experiment. There are upon the Babcock lot many scrub grown Oaks, kept down by the cropping of the cattle. And there are some dying and dead Oaks which it will be proper for me to have cut down, and brought home for fuel— We dined, sitting down upon Stones in a Corner of Harvey Field’s yard, and finished about five in the afternoon— I agreed with Mr Humphreys to commence the Survey of Mount Wollaston this day fortnight, if the weather should be fair— I picked up also four or five wild pears for seed on the Druid plain, and Farrar gathered me some fox grapes. I walked home over the Stony-field Hill— Found the Shellbark Walnuts near the Old Trask house, already mostly
carried off— I gathered some ashpods from the tree. I have taken them at different periods of the Season to multiply the chances of their germinating as seed— On returning home I found the child yet very ill. Mr Marston’s daughter Emily died last night of a Consumption— John Kirke went to Boston this Morning, and brought out the Horse Charles has kept this Summer. He took to Mr Newman’s at Roxbury one of the Coach-horses which is lame— I attempted reading in the Evening some Sections de Officiis, but was too weary and drowsy—
28. IV:15. Tuesday.

A restless and all but wholly sleepless Night— The child crying with little intermission until four this morning, and her Grandmother up with her till that hour— To aggravate our anxiety we do not positively know what her disease is—though apparently an ulcerated mouth and sore throat— She has cried and shrieked herself excessively hoarse— She has yet two double teeth to come— I revisited my Nursery— Planted a row of Cap white Oaks acorns all sprouted intermixed with Horse Chesnuts, and Shellbarks—and overlaid them with another row of whole Peaches and Pears with one Plumstone— This row is next to and crossing the row of Charles’s young Elm— I have been instructed to plant Acorns, nuts and stones 4 inches, and seeds and berries only two inches beneath the surface of the ground. But I bring my Nuts and Acorns at least 6. inches; and some of the seeds in the second row are four inches deep and more— I usually place the stake between the upper and lower layer and plant deeper than the English Gardners direct, because the seed are to lie a winter in the ground before coming up, and because our winter frosts strike deeper than in England— I threw in at a ventures several buttons from the button wood tree— Marked the cap white Oaks with stake and Stone, and planted in like manner a sinking pig nut between the Book boxes 1. and 2. in the garden. The two black Oak worms, which I took from the tree on the 16th. and which I have kept under a glass and fed with black oak leaves, since yesterday cast off their Caterpillar skins, and have turned to grubs. This afternoon Professor Hitchcock employed by the Legislature to examine the Geology of the territory of the State, to aid in the composition of a map of the Commonwealth, called here with a Mr Holmes from Boston, and made some enquiries respecting the extent of the Slate Quarries in the Town of Quincy which I was not altogether able to answer— Such information as I possessed I gave him; and he walked with me over upon Stony field hill, and examined the Rocks and Stones which abound upon it— Mr Krehmer came out with my Son Charles, this evening from Boston, and paid us a visit— Mr Thomas Greenleaf spent an hour of the Evening with me— He knew as little about the Slate quarries as I did; and we agreed to go together in a short time and see them— We spoke of the Plan of the 8. Acre lot, made by Mr Fuller and which has been adopted by the Town— And also of the expediency of having a classical school established in the Town as soon as possible— The town has received within the last year a severe check in the removal to Sandy-bay of a considerable number of the Stone-Cutters— A number of houses has been evacuated, and the population of the Town has decreased— The prospect is that this will prove a permanent loss to the Town, and will have an inauspicious influence upon all improvement within it— Mr Greenleaf mentioned also the subject of the approaching Congressional election, and expressed the opinion that I have no justifiable cause for declining— I took 3 Shellbarks from the garden tree— Their ripeness appears from the easy opening of the drupe—
29— V. Wednesday.

The child had another distressing and painful Night— Ours was almost sleepless. My wife with her till 3. this Morning. Sent for Dr Holbrook early— The Disease of the Child is Canker in the Mouth and throat: She suffers less in the day time than in the Night. This was a day of military training and review at the Bridge point; and of excessive bustle round the whole neighbourhood— A continual stream of Gigs, Carryall, Stages, and waggons, rattled over the roads to and fro, from 5 this morning till ten at Night. Planted in the Nursery a row of Druid Chesnut Oak Acorns, with stake and Stone, alternating with Horse Chesnuts and Shellbarks— In the line above them, Beech Stones from Medford, brought yesterday by Charles. Pear Cores and Apple seeds. Began a new Trench, from the middle old Appletree towards the Gate. After dinner I walked over the Hill— Gathered a few of the Stranger Berries, which are not yet ripe, and a few Ashpods which are dry— I found the Trask Shellbark trees which were half stripp’d of their Nuts on Monday wholly disburthened of them now— A few at the tops of the trees, too high to be reached are all that remain. The day was uninterrupted, excepting by anxieties for the child, and I wrote accordingly—
30. IV:15. Thursday.

John’s Child is yet very ill; and the Night was almost as much disturbed as those which preceded. But Dr Holbrook who was here this morning thought her better than yesterday. There was training of Militia Companies again this day, in all autumnal beauty— Kindled a fire, the first time this Season in my library. Fahrenheit at 55. In the Nursery, planted a row of Druid white Oak Acorns and Shellbarks alternate— Above them a row of Medford Peach Stones— Ash pods, Wild Cherries, Pear Cores and Appleseeds. I plant the rows in this patch 18 inches apart— The two brothers Everett, with their wives paid us a morning visit; and they were followed by General Dearborn, his daughter and two Sons. Mr Wingate of Portland and his wife, and their daughter Mrs Clap with the two Misses Crowninshield. The new revolution in France and its probable consequences form the topic of all Conversations. A. H. Everett asked me if I had received the new number of the North American Review. I had not, he said it was this day published and contained a Letter from Mr Madison against the South Carolina nullification nonsense. Judge Johnson too of the Supreme Court of the United States, he said had also come forth against it, and in favour of the Constitutionality of the Tariff. I asked Mr Wingate if they had a Governor in Maine. He said he was afraid they had. I took a late ride with Mrs Adams this afternoon, and spent the Evening at Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s— I found him, and his wife, with Thomas Greenleaf and his wife at a whist party— The mode in which they pass a great portion of their Winter Evenings— Daniel Greenleaf asked me if I was an inhabitant of Quincy, and said he had been asked the question— I said if I was an inhabitant any where, it was of Quincy, and I had been so taken with my family in the census— The question arises from my having been an inhabitant of Boston, till the close of my Service as President of the United States—and from my having resided since then, part of the Time at Washington. Mr Greenleaf said he had answered that he received from the Judge of Probate of this County a Commission in relation to the Execution of my father’s Will, in which I was styled of Quincy.

Day. Like that of July and August, excepting as modified by the change of the Season; and by the departure of my two Sons and of Robert C. Buchanan—that of Charles’s wife, with him; and the Confinement of John’s wife, have reduced the social Circle of the family to its two heads— Sea bathing has ceased, and I am to be thankful that my Catarrhal cough has almost left me— I continue to take sudorific exercise, of which my garden Nursery, and my seed planting hobby furnish me the means— It has had a good effect upon my health, and scarcely a day passes; but I labour from two to three hours with the spade and the hoe, and deposit some seed nut or stone in the ground, with the hope that it may re-appear as a plant, next Spring. My series of experiments is neither scientific; nor perhaps judicious, but the thought that the result of them may be useful hereafter to others sustains me in pursuing them— The reflection which most weighs with me is that if it had commenced in my youth, and steadily persevered into this time, I should now be reaping a harvest of abundant fruits, and enjoying perhaps the shade of a lofty forest— That which might now have been mine, may with the blessing of Heaven be the comfort of my Grandchildren the next Century; and if there be to the all-seeing eye, and the all controuling Will, presumption in the wish, there yet may be other future human beings, whose enjoyments will be increased by my plantations— In the mean time, graver things are neglected, and I lead a life of idleness— I read the Bible— Illustrative fragments appended to the English Translation of Calmet’s Dictionary; and the works of Cicero. With these last I am drawing to a close, and yet ask myself what benefit I have derived from a persevering study of ten Months, and which will extend to a full year— This diary is the last of my persevering pursuits; and it absorbs large portions of my time— I am now closing a volume with the intention of beginning upon another to-morrow— There are large interruptions during the period while I was in the Administration of the Government— Some of them are supplied in other volumes— Some never can be supplied— A Diary of detail can not be kept by a public man, whose time slips away from the discharge even of many important duties— Since my retirement mine has been regularly kept, but it has been a record of crude thoughts, and of Events calamitous or trifling— With a Soul full of gratitude to the giver of all good gifts, for blessings yet enjoyed, and in humble supplication for those yet suited to my wants, I pray for Prudence, Temperance, Fortitude, Justice, and Christian Charity, for a still merciful Creator, for purification of heart for energy of purpose, for resignation to his will, and I shut the book.
